thread.title: US Dollar Index Gains as ADP Non-Farm Payrolls Rise - Yahoo Finance
thread.title_full: US Dollar Index Gains as ADP Non-Farm Payrolls Rise - Yahoo Finance

author: David Meyer
title: US Dollar Index Gains as ADP Non-Farm Payrolls Rise - Yahoo Finance
text:
Foreign Exchange Indicators across the US, Canada, and Switzerland 
( Continued from Prior Part )
US ADP non-farm payrolls beat forecasts According to the ADP National Employment Report published on September 30, 2015, private sector employment figures rose by 200,000 in September. These figures were above the forecast of 192,000 and were also above the previous month’s figures of 186,000.
The biggest increase was seen within large businesses with more than a thousand employees. Their figures rose by 109,000. In terms of sector, the services sector witnessed a majority of the employment growth, with a rise of 188,000.
In terms of industry, the manufacturing industry was the only industry in which jobs were lost. Its employment figures fell by 15,000. The rest of the industries showed positive job growth with the trade, transportation, and utilities sector leading the pack.
US dollar posts solid gains Decent payroll numbers gave the US Dollar Index a much-needed boost. Though the market had been awaiting a speech by Janet Yellen, Chair of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, in St. Louis, there was hardly any mention of monetary policy in Yellen’s speech.
The Chicago purchasing managers’ index came out for the month of September on a negative note at 48.7. But the major driver for the day was the payroll numbers, which seemed to support a case for a rate hike this year. The US Dollar Index rose to a high of 96.40 before closing the day with a rise of 0.44% at 96.28.

Impact on the market The iShares Transportation Average ETF (IYT) posted a gain of 1.15%, and the SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT) rose by 1.42% on September 30, 2015.
The automobile sector was on a positive trend with Ford (F) and General Motors (GM) rising by 3.19% and 2.98%, respectively. In the retail segment, Wal-Mart (WMT) rose by 1.66%.
